'''''Takahashi v. Fish and Game Comm'n''''', 334 U.S. 410 (1948), was a case before the [[United States Supreme Court]]. The issue at hand was a restrictive law in California requiring American citizenship to get a fishing license. The Court held that this was an unreasonable restriction and was discriminatory to residents of Japanese ancestry.
==Background==
===Facts=== Torao Takahashi came from Japan to the United States and became a resident of [[Terminal Island]] in Los Angeles County, California in 1907. Prior to 1943 California issued commercial fishing licenses to all qualified persons without regard to alienage or ineligibility to citizenship. From 1915 to 1942 Takahashi, under annual commercial fishing licenses issued by the State, fished in ocean waters off the California coast, apparently both within and without the three-mile coastal belt, and brought his fresh fish ashore for sale. In 1942, while the United States country was at war with Japan, Takahashi and other California residents of Japanese ancestry were [[Japanese American internment|forcibly interned]] under military orders. The evacuation was legally challenged in ''[[Korematsu v. United States]]'' but a majority of the U.S. Supreme Court upheld the evacuation.
In 1943, during the period of war and evacuation, an amendment to the California Fish and Game Code was adopted prohibiting issuance of a license to any "alien Japanese."<ref>Cal. Stats. 1943, ch. 1100.</ref> In 1945, the state code was again amended by striking the 1943 provision for fear that it might be "declared unconstitutional" because directed only "against alien Japanese"; the new amendment banned issuance of licenses to any "person ineligible to citizenship," which classification included Japanese. Cal. Stats. 1945, ch. 181. Because of this state provision barring issuance of commercial fishing licenses to persons ineligible for citizenship under federal law, Takahashi, who met all other state requirements, was denied a license by the [[California Department of Fish and Wildlife|California Fish and Game Commission]] upon his return to California in 1945.
===Claim===
Takahashi, an alien ineligible for citizenship, brought an action for mandamus in the Superior Court of Los Angeles County, California, to compel the Commission to issue him a commercial fishing license.
===California Superior Court===
The Superior Court first ordered issuance of a commercial fishing license authorizing Takahashi to bring ashore "catches of fish from the waters of the high seas beyond the State's territorial jurisdiction."
After appeal to the State Supreme Court by the State Commission the Superior Court amended its judgment so as to order a commercial license authorizing Takahashi to bring in catches of fish taken from the three-mile ocean belt adjacent to the California coast as well as from the high seas. It held that lawful alien inhabitants of California, despite their ineligibility to citizenship, were entitled to engage in the vocation of commercial fishing on the high seas beyond the three-mile belt on the same terms as other lawful state inhabitants, and that the California code provision denying them this right violated the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
===Supreme Court of California=== A judgment granting the writ was reversed by the State Supreme Court, three judges dissenting.
The Court held that California had a proprietary interest in fish in the ocean waters within three miles of the shore, and that this interest justified the State in barring all aliens in general and aliens ineligible to citizenship in particular from catching fish within or without the three-mile coastal belt and bringing them to California for commercial purposes. 30 Cal. 2d 719, 185 P. 2d 805.
The state court held that this interest justified the state in barring all aliens in general, and aliens ineligible for citizenship in particular, from catching fish within or without the three-mile coastal belt and bringing them into the state for commercial purposes.
===Certiorari and arguments=== The Supreme Court granted certiorari. 333 U.S. 853, "to review this question of importance in the fields of federal-state relationships and of constitutionally protected individual equality and liberty".
==Opinion of the court==
The Court reversed. [[Hugo Black|Justice Black]] was joined by six other justices.
It held that the California statute forbidding the issuance of commercial fishing licenses to aliens ineligible to citizenship was held to violate the constitutional right of such aliens to the equal protection of the laws. The contention that the statute might be supported as a conservation measure was rejected. The state could not, consistent with the United States Constitution, use federally created racial ineligibility for citizenship as a basis for barring petitioner from earning his living as a commercial fisherman in the ocean water off the state coast. The refusal to issue petitioner a commercial fishing license violated U.S. Const. amend. XIV, and there was no special public interest to support the state ban on petitioner's commercial fishing.
A state prohibition of the issuance of commercial fishing licenses to persons ineligible to citizenship makes an unreasonable classification in violation of the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment (distinguishing ''[[Terrace v. Thompson]]'', 263 US 197; ''[[Porterfield v. Webb]]'', 263 US 225; ''[[Webb v. O'Brien]]'', 263 US 313; and ''[[Frick v. Webb]]'', 263 US 326).
1. A California statute barring issuance of commercial fishing licenses to persons "ineligible to citizenship," which classification included resident alien Japanese and precluded such a one from earning his living as a commercial fisherman in the ocean waters off the coast of the State, held invalid under the Federal Constitution and laws. pp. 412–422.
2. For purposes of decision by this Court, it may be assumed that the object of the statute was to conserve fish in the coastal waters of the State, or to protect citizens of the State engaged in commercial fishing from the competition of Japanese aliens, or both. P. 418.
3. That the United States regulates immigration and naturalization in part on the basis of race and color classifications does not authorize adoption by a State of such classifications to prevent lawfully admitted aliens within its borders from earning a livelihood by means open to all other inhabitants. pp. 418–420.
4. The Fourteenth Amendment and federal laws, 8 U. S. C. § 41, embody a general policy that all persons lawfully in this country shall abide "in any state" on an equality of legal privileges with all citizens under non-discriminatory laws. pp. 419–420.
5. Whatever may be the interest of the State or its citizens in the fish in the 3-mile belt offshore, that interest does not justify the State in excluding any or all aliens who are lawful residents of the State from making a living by fishing in the ocean off its shores while permitting all other persons to do so. pp. 420–421.
6. Assuming their continued validity, cases sustaining state laws barring land ownership by aliens ineligible to citizenship, which rested on grounds peculiar to real property, can not be extended to control the decision in this case. P. 422.
===Concurrence=== [[Frank Murphy|Justice Murphy]], joined by [[Wiley B. Rutledge|Rutledge]], expressed agreement with these views, but thought that the statute should also be condemned as being the direct outgrowth of antagonism toward persons of Japanese ancestry and as having no relation whatever to any constitutionally cognizable interest of California.
===Dissent=== [[Stanley F. Reed|Justice Reed]], joined by [[Robert H. Jackson|Jackson]], dissented on the ground that a state has the power to exclude all aliens from enjoyment of its natural resources, including its fisheries, and that a classification excluding such aliens as are ineligible to citizenship is not unreasonable.
==See also== * ''[[Fish Canneries Reference]]'': a similar case in British Columbia * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 334]]

[[United Artists]] |released = {{Film date|1978|02|09}} |runtime = 125 m |language = [[English language|English]] |budget = }} '''''The Betsy''''' is a [[1978 in film|1978]] film made by the Harold Robbins International Company and released by [[Allied Artists Pictures Corporation|Allied Artists]] and [[United Artists]].PA0000241949 / 1984-12-13 ([[United States Copyright Office]]) It was directed by [[Daniel Petrie]] and produced by Robert R. Weston and Emanuel L. Wolf with Jack Grossberg as associate producer. The [[screenplay]] was by [[William Bast]] and [[Walter Bernstein]], adapted from the novel of the same title by [[Harold Robbins]].{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=7EKfL5z8xYAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Betsy+film |title=The Betsy |first=Harold |last=Robbins |publisher=AuthorHouse |year=2011 |isbn=9781463413750 |edition=eBook |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} The film stars [[Laurence Olivier]], [[Robert Duvall]], [[Katharine Ross]], [[Tommy Lee Jones]], [[Jane Alexander]], [[Joseph Wiseman]], [[Kathleen Beller]], [[Edward Herrmann]], [[Paul Ryan Rudd]], and [[Lesley-Anne Down]]. The novelist reportedly considered ''The Betsy'' the "best movie adaptation of any of his works."{{cite web|title=William Bast recalls the making of ''The Betsy'' |publisher=American Legends |url= http://www.americanlegends.com/Interviews/bill_bast_interview.html |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} == Plot == A fading family-owned [[automobile manufacturer]] and its owners pin their hopes for a return to profitability on a new model named for the great-granddaughter of the firm's founder. The aging Loren Hardeman Sr. remains the titular head of a Detroit automotive conglomerate. (An obvious parallel exists between this fictional character and that of [[Henry Ford]].) His grandson, Loren Hardeman III, now runs the company as president, but has diversified into other fields and is concerned that the auto division is not as lucrative as it once was and might even need to be eliminated. A young auto racer, Angelo Perino, has been secretly commissioned to develop a ground-breaking fuel-efficient car. He juggles romantic relationships with a British royal, Lady Bobby Ayres, and the young Betsy, who is about to turn 21 and inherit a fortune, including the new car her great-grandfather is naming in her honor. Loren Hardeman III bitterly despises Hardeman Sr., who once carried on an affair with Loren's mother. The older Hardeman is not the man he used to be, but neither is he ready to step aside forever. ==Cast== * [[Laurence Olivier]] as Loren Hardeman Sr. * [[Tommy Lee Jones]] as Angelo Perino * [[Robert Duvall]] as Loren Hardeman III * [[Katharine Ross]] as Sally Hardeman * [[Jane Alexander]] as Alicia Hardeman * [[Lesley-Anne Down]] as Lady Ayres * [[Kathleen Beller]] as Betsy * [[Joseph Wiseman]] as Jake Weinstein * [[Edward Herrmann]] as Dan Weyman * [[Paul Ryan Rudd]] as Loren Hardeman Jr. * [[Charlie Fields]] as young Loren Hardeman III ==Production== Assembly-plant footage was filmed at the [[American Motors]] (AMC) [[Kenosha, Wisconsin]] factory. It shows 1978 [[AMC Gremlin|Gremlin]], [[AMC Pacer|Pacer]], and [[AMC Concord|Concord]] models being built and painted on AMC's assembly line serving as the factory of the fictitious Bethlehem Motors.{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=r9j7MWLE_jMC&pg=PA247&lpg=PA247&dq=The+Betsy+AMC |title=The Cars of American Motors: An Illustrated History|first=Marc |last=Cranswick |publisher=McFarland |year=2011 |isbn=978-0-7864-4672-8 |page=247 |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} For authenticity, the movie producers had queried AMC on how a new car is developed.{{cite journal|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=N8laAAAAYAAJ&q=The+Betsy+producers+queried+AMC+on+how+a+new+car+was+developed |journal=Ward's Auto World |volume=13 |page=37 |title='The Betsy' |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} The titular car is a slightly modified 1974 [[Lancia Beta]] coupe.{{cite web|url= http://www.imcdb.org/vehicle_324856-Lancia-Beta-Coupe-1974.html |title=1974 Lancia Beta Coupe |publisher=Internet Movie Cars Database |year=2010 |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} ''The Betsy'' features music composed by [[John Barry (composer)|John Barry]].{{cite web|title=The Betsy (1978) |publisher=movies.com |year=2007 |url= http://www.movies.com/betsy/details/m46636 |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} It was filmed at [[Rosecliff]] mansion in [[Newport, Rhode Island]]. Review by an automobile industry expert noted that filmmakers have not shown believable characters and realistic dialogue.{{cite journal |url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/09/20/autos/big_three_hollywod.fortune/ |title=The Big Three on the Big Screen |first=Alex |last=Taylor III |journal=Fortune |date=20 September 2011 |accessdate=14 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214171809/http://money.cnn.com/2011/09/20/autos/big_three_hollywod.fortune/ |archivedate=14 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Attempts by Hollywood to capture the auto industry on film, such as ''The Betsy'', have "aimed at realistic drama but wound up with suds." In 1978 in United States there was a notable increase in construction of [[racquetball]] courts in the country and the director chose to shoot a scene in a company racquetball court during first meeting between the character played by [[Tommy Lee Jones]] and [[Robert Duvall]]. == Notes == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{cite news|last=Maslin |first=Janet |title=The Betsy (1978) Screen: Of Cars, Sex Money and 'The Betsy': Family Affair |newspaper=The New York Times |date=10 February 1978 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?_r=1&res=9803E5DC1430E632A25753C1A9649C946990D6CF |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} * {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Hoe6syHCSIC&pg=PA157&dq=The+Betsy+film |pages=157–159 |title=The Politics and Poetics of Camp |editor-first=Morris |editor-last=Meyer |publisher=Routledge |year=1994 |isbn=9780415082471 |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} * {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IDFyB8SwsTMC&pg=PA201&dq=The+Betsy+1978+cast+Laurence+Olivier |pages=199–201 |title=The Complete Films of Laurence Olivier |editor-first=Jerry |editor-last=Vermilye |publisher=Carol Publishing Group |year=1992 |isbn=9780806513027 |accessdate=14 December 2013 }} * {{IMDb title|0077228|The Betsy}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|betsy}} {{Daniel Petrie}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Betsy, The}} [[Category:1978 films]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] [[Category:American business films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American Motors]] [[Category:Films about automobiles]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Films scored by John Barry (composer)]] [[Category:Films directed by Daniel Petrie]] [[Category:Films set in Michigan]] [[Category:United Artists films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Walter Bernstein]] [[Category:Cars designed and produced for films]] [[Category:1970s business films]]

'''Tlamemeh''' is a word that comes from the [[Nahuatl]] tlamama, meaning load. In [[Honduras]] and [[Mexico]] it means Indian laborer. The porters carried loads on their backs (which could be people, taxes, or items for trade).
In colonial times the tradition implied the servitude of the Indians, who in most cases became [[vassals]] of the Spanish which became widespread. Today, in [[Mexican Spanish]], the word tameme is usually a derogatory connotation of "subordinate" that denotes the discrimination from the Indian that was consolidated in the new Colony of Spain.
==History== [[File:Pochtecas con su carga.JPG|230px|thumb|Tlamemeh according to the [[Florentine Codex]]]] In pre-Hispanic Mexico, and generally throughout [[Mesoamerica]], there was not any animal capable of being used in the loading and transport of goods and so manpower had to be used, this is how the "tameme" emerged. From the arrival of the Spanish in the area (first expeditions starting in 1493), they began to replace porters with animals such as horses carrying the [[conquest (military)|conquerors]], but were not specifically brought to be used for burden but for combat, so the porters were still widely used.
==Job characteristics==
[[Miguel León-Portilla]], described tlamemes as "porters trained from childhood", from the class of commoners [[macehualtin]], devoted exclusively to freight in the [[Aztec]] culture." They began to exercise since childhood, carrying on average 23 kilos and did a daily commute of 21 to 25 kilometers before being relieved .
With the Spanish conquest in 1521 the first domestic species of cargo animals arrived, but they continued to use tlamemes because of a lack of roads. They were considered of lower status in the social scale, only slightly higher than the simple soldiers of the Aztec military. [[Porters]] that were located on the outside of the markets or swap meets, provided services transporting purchases, but the most important were the porters who served in the expeditions of the merchants.
Before leaving in each convoy, merchants carefully calculated the number of porters that would accompany them, taking into account the duration of the trip, the number of casualties possible in the course, etc. . They carried all the goods that the merchants would sell on the trip, which often lasted for months. When the expedition reached a resting place, they were granted special attention to the through the night, so they could recover from their strenuous efforts, recognizing the value of their work. When they returned to base, the expedition porters were engaged in periods of rest, not acting in the tianguis(stores)q, or mingling with the other porters.
In remote areas or for economic reasons, this profession continues even today.
==Applications and tools==
The porters used a "backstrap" in their work, which was a wide, thick leather strap with a mecate(cord) at each end that served to hold and keep the load stable to the back of the tlameme. In some, mecapales([[textiles]]) and wood structures were used.
==Sources==
*Sherman, William. Trabajo Forzado nativo en Siglo XVI América Central, University of Nebraska Press, Nebraska, 1979; *Newson, Linda. La supervivencia de la India en Colonial Nicaragua, University of Oklahoma Press, Oklahoma, 1987; *Barrantes, Ramiro. Evolución en el trópico. Los Amerindios de Costa Rica y Panamá, Editorial Universidad de Costa Rica, San José, 1993. Libro en línea: [1] *Denevan, William, la población indígena de las Américas en 1492, la población indígena de las Américas en 1492, Madison, University of Wisconsin Press, Madison, 1992 (Edición Segunda).

'''Antoin "Tony" Rezko''' (born 1955) is an American businessman. He was a fundraiser for Illinois [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politicians. After becoming a major contributor to [[Rod Blagojevich]]'s successful gubernatorial election, Rezko assisted Blagojevich in setting up the state's first Democratic administration in twenty years and as a result he was able to have business associates appointed onto several state boards. Rezko and several others were indicted on federal charges in October 2006 for using their connections on the state boards to demand [[Political corruption#Kickbacks|kickbacks]] from businesses that wished to engage in dealings with the state. While the others pleaded guilty, Rezko pleaded not guilty and was tried. He was found guilty of 16 of the 24 charges filed against him and on November 23, 2011, he was sentenced to 10.5 years in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://posttrib.suntimes.com/news/politics/9001435-418/tony-rezko-sentenced-to-10-12-years-in-kickback-scheme.html|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=2012-01-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129212145/http://posttrib.suntimes.com/news/politics/9001435-418/tony-rezko-sentenced-to-10-12-years-in-kickback-scheme.html|archivedate=2011-11-29|df=}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Tony Rezko was born in 1955 in [[Aleppo, Syria]], to a prominent [[Syriac Catholic Church|Syriac Catholic]] family.<ref name=chicagomag>{{cite web|url=http://chicagomag.com/core/pagetools.php?pageid=7030&url=%2FChicago-Magazine%2FNovember-2007%2FMr-Inside-Out%2F&mode=print|title=Mr. Inside Out|publisher=Chicago Magazine|author=Merriner, James L.|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> After graduating from college there, Rezko moved to [[Chicago]] and earned an undergraduate and a master's degree in civil engineering from the [[Illinois Institute of Technology]] in the late 1970s. He joined an engineering company, designing [[nuclear power]] plants, then left to design roads for the state Transportation Department, making $21,590 in his first year there.<ref name=Fund-raising>{{Cite news|last=Jackson|first=David|last2=Chase|first2=John|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-0610120112oct12,0,3093652.story|title=Rezko's life a story of pizza and politics|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=2006-10-12|accessdate=2007-02-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227041817/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-0610120112oct12,0,3093652.story|archivedate=2007-12-27|df=}}</ref><ref name=Novak2>{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/355099,cst-nws-rez24a.article|title=Broken promises, broken homes|work=Chicago Sun-Times|author=Novak, Tim|date=2007-04-24|accessdate=2008-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080324131917/http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/355099,cst-nws-rez24a.article|archivedate=2008-03-24|df=}}</ref>
==Career== While he was an engineer, Rezko started buying vacant lots and developing single family residences. He also began investing in [[fast-food]] restaurants, including the first [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]] in Chicago. Many properties were in lower-income [[African American]] neighborhoods<ref name=chicagomag/><ref name=salon/> where he met Jabir Herbert (J.H.) Muhammad, former manager of heavyweight champion [[Muhammad Ali]] and son of the late [[Nation of Islam]] leader, [[Elijah Muhammad]]. Rezko was asked in 1983 to support the successful mayoral candidacy of African-American [[Harold Washington]]. J.H. Muhammad's company, Crucial Concessions, hired Rezko in 1984 and won a food contract on Lake Michigan beaches and in many South Side parks. Rezko put together endorsement deals for Ali, became the executive director of the Muhammad Ali Foundation, and traveled the world with Ali for five years.<ref name=chicagomag/>
In 1997, Crucial Concessions opened two [[Panda Express]] Restaurants at O'Hare, under the city's minority set-aside program. It lost those franchises in 2005, on the grounds that J.H. Muhammad was merely a front man for Rezko, who had been appointed trustee of Elijah Muhammad's affairs in the early 1990s. In March 2008 Muhammad sued Rezko, alleging that he had been swindled out of his home and business interests.<ref name=Novak2/><ref name=salon>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2008/02/01/rezko/print.html|title=How close were Barack Obama and Tony Rezko?|publisher=Salon|author=McClelland, Edward|date=2008-02-01|accessdate=2008-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418205340/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2008/02/01/rezko/print.html|archivedate=2008-04-18|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/14/us/politics/14rezko.html?_r=1&oref=slogin&pagewanted=print|title=An Obama Patron and Friend Until an Indictment|work=The New York Times|date=2007-06-14|accessdate=2008-05-10|first1=Christopher|last1=Drew|first2=Mike|last2=McIntire}}</ref>
In January 1989, Rezko and attorney Daniel Mahru, CEO of a firm that leased ice makers to bars and hotels, founded a real-estate development and restaurant holding corporation called Rezmar Corporation. Between 1989 and 1998, Rezmar rehabilitated 30 buildings, a total of 1,025 apartments, spending more than $100 million from the city, state and federal governments and bank loans. Rezko and Mahru weren't responsible for any government or bank loans or the $50 million in federal tax credits they got to rehab the buildings. Rezmar put just $100 into each project and got a 1% stake as the general partner in charge of hiring the architect, contractor, and the company that would manage the buildings. They selected Chicago Property Management, also owned by Rezko and Mahru, to manage the buildings, including selecting the tenants and making repairs. Rezmar also got upfront development fees of at least $6.9 million in all. Under its deals with the Chicago Equity Fund, Rezmar promised to cover all operating losses in any building for seven years, but had no obligation after that, although the Federal Government could recover the tax credits that Rezmar sold from the holders if the projects did not survive for fifteen years or more.<ref name=Novak2/> By 1998 the company had a net worth of [[United States dollar|US$]]34 million<ref name=Novak>{{cite news|author=Novak, Tim|title=Obama and his Rezko ties|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=2007-04-23|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/353829,CST-NWS-rez23.article|accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> and it then turned to purchasing old factories and parcels of land in [[gentrification|gentrifying]] areas of Chicago and turning them into upscale condominium complexes.<ref name=Novak2/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=87830023|title=Q&A: The Tony Rezko Case|author=David Schaper|date=2008-03-06|accessdate=2008-03-09}}</ref> Rezko was named "Entrepreneur of the Decade" by the Arab-American Business and Professional Association.<ref name=hanania>{{cite web|url=http://www.themediaoasis.com/profiles/Rezko06-08-05.htm|title=Arabs in Chicago discover political clout and controversy|author=Ray Hanania|publisher=Arab American Media Services|date=2005-06-08|accessdate=2008-01-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080915132137/http://www.themediaoasis.com/profiles/Rezko06-08-05.htm|archivedate=2008-09-15|df=}}</ref>
Rezko's investment in restaurant food chains had started with a chain of [[Panda Express]] Chinese restaurants. In 1998, Rezko opened his first chain of [[Papa John's Pizza]] restaurants in Chicago and by 2002, he had twenty-six stores in Chicago, at least fifteen in [[Wisconsin]], and seven in Detroit, part of the financing for these stores was through [[GE Capital]].<ref name=Fund-raising/> By 2001, Rezko began to fall behind on his franchise payments and loans and he transferred the franchises to several business associates. In 2006, during a lawsuit with Papa John's over his franchise fees, Rezko renamed his Papa John's restaurants to Papa Tony's.<ref name=hanania/> Rezko also had a lien filed against his home after losing a civil lawsuit to GE Capital.<ref name=Fund-raising/>
As his business ventures began failing, Rezko entered into several partnership with Iraqi-born business executive [[Nadhmi Auchi]], including a massive 2005 real estate development project on Chicago's [[Chicago Loop|South Loop]] whose value was pegged by an observer familiar with the deal at $130.5 million.<ref name="chibus">[http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/news.pl?id=17946 Rezko sells Loop project for $131M]</ref> In 2008, Rezko was imprisoned for his failure to disclose a $3.5m loan from Auchi.
==Legal troubles== Rezko was later convicted on 16 charges of corruption and fraud and was sentenced to serve 10 1/2 years in prison.
===Public corruption charges=== In October 2006, Rezko was indicted along with businessman Stuart Levine on charges of wire fraud, bribery, money laundering, and attempted extortion as a result of a federal investigation known as "Operation Board Games."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/downloads/rezkoindict.pdf|title=Indictment - U.S. vs. Levine and Rezko|format=PDF |publisher=Chicago Business | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,335592,00.html | title=Courtroom Wire: Notes From Tony Rezko's Corruption Trial | publisher=FOXNews | author=Marla Cichowski | date=2008-04-04 | accessdate=2008-04-06}}</ref> Levine was once a top Republican fund-raiser who had switched loyalty in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/cgi-bin/news.pl?id=22634&seenIt=1|title=Chicago Business News--Stuart Levine Pleads Guilty}}</ref> Rezko and Levine were charged with attempting to extort millions of dollars from businesses seeking to do business with the Illinois Teachers System Board and the Illinois Health Facilities Planning Board from 2002 to 2004. Levine pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against Rezko and others. While the charges carry a maximum sentence of life in prison, Levine expects to receive about a 5-1/2 year sentence in return for his testimony.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-rezko-19mar19,0,5503877.story | title=Levine weaves tawdry tale | work=Chicago Tribune | author=Secter, Bob |author2=Coen, Jeff | date=2008-03-19 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> The case was prosecuted by [[Patrick Fitzgerald]].
Rezko pleaded not guilty, and the trial related to his charges from Operation Board Games began on March 6, 2008.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-0307edit1mar07,1,5412814.story | archive-url=https://archive.is/20081214193252/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/chi-0307edit1mar07,1,5412814.story | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2008-12-14 | title=One Tony, three trials | work=Chicago Tribune | date=2008-03-07 | accessdate=2008-05-10 }} </ref> He was jailed shortly before the trial began when he received a $3.5 million wire transfer from Lebanon. Rezko had told the court that he had no access to money from overseas. Ten weeks into the trial, on April 18, Judge Amy St. Eve released Rezko, after friends and relatives put up 30 properties valued at about $8.5 million to secure his bond. Prosecutors opposed the motion for release, saying that Rezko was a flight risk.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-rezko-fridayapr20,1,7431091.story | title=Rezko free on bail |work= Chicago Tribune |author= Coen, Jeff |date= 2008-04-20 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> On May 6, both the prosecution and the defense rested their cases. Government prosecutors spent 8 weeks presenting their case. Rezko’s lawyer, Joseph J. Duffy, chose not to present any witnesses, saying that he did not believe that the prosecution had proven the charges.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/06/us/06brfs-002.html?ref=us | title=Illinois: No Defense Witnesses for Rezko | work=The New York Times | author=Einhorn Catrin | date=2008-05-06 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> Prosecutors contended that they had shown Rezko's "corrupt use of his power and influence" to gain benefits for himself and his friends. Duffy argued that the prosecution had exaggerated Rezko's influence in state government, and attacked Levine's credibility as a witness.<ref>[http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-rezko_for_tuesdaymay13,0,553455.story Corrupt mastermind or victim of frame-up?] Chicago Tribune, May 13, 2008</ref>
The case went to the jury on May 13 and after three weeks of deliberation, the jury found Rezko guilty of six counts of wire fraud, six counts of mail fraud, two counts of corrupt solicitation, and two counts of money laundering, but found him not guilty on three counts of wire and mail fraud, one count of attempted extortion, and four counts of corrupt solicitation.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/politics&id=6185320 | title=Rezko found guilty on 16 counts | publisher=ABCNews | date=2008-06-04 | accessdate=2008-06-04}}</ref> According to CBS News the "high-profile federal trial provided an unusually detailed glimpse of the pay-to-play politics that has made Illinois infamous."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cbs2chicago.com/local/rezko.trial.verdict.2.740375.html |title=Jury Finds Tony Rezko Guilty On 16 Of 24 Charges |publisher=CBS 2 |author=Parker, Mike |date=2008-06-04 |accessdate=2008-06-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605063726/http://cbs2chicago.com/local/rezko.trial.verdict.2.740375.html |archivedate=2008-06-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
While the jury was deliberating on the Board Games trial, an arrest warrant was issued in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] for passing bad checks in two casinos and failing to pay $450,000 in gambling debts that were accrued between March and July 2006.<ref name=Casino_debt>{{cite news | url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/rezko/977195,rezkogamble052908.article | title=Las Vegas judge issues arrest warrant for Tony Rezko over alleged gambling debts | work=Chicago Sun-Times | author=Korecki, Natasha |authorlink=Natasha Korecki| date=2008-05-29 | accessdate=2008-06-11}}</ref> Another casino had also filed a civil complaint for a total of $331,000 in 2006 and was given a judgment of default in 2007.<ref name=Casino_debt/>
===Charges related to private business dealings=== Rezko was indicted, along with a business associate, for wire fraud related to the alleged sale of his pizza business to a straw buyer at an inflated price in order to obtain millions of dollars in loans from [[GE Capital]].<ref>{{cite news | author=Robinson, Mike | title=Blagojevich Adviser Indicted on Charges | work=The Washington Post | date=2006-10-11 | accessdate=2007-03-17 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/11/AR2006101100918.html}}</ref> Rezko initially pleaded not guilty to these charges.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-rezkojun08,0,3297509.story | title=Rezko faces next trial: Date set in pizza case | work=Chicago Tribune | date=2008-06-08 | accessdate=2008-06-11 | first1=Stacy | last1=St Clair | first2=Jodi S | last2=Cohen}}</ref> In 2011, Rezko would change his plea to guilty.<ref name=uqovz>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/22/tony-rezko-sentenced-blag_n_1165774.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Tony Rezko Sentenced: Former Blagojevich Fundraiser Won't Serve More Time For New Conviction | date=2011-12-22}}</ref> As part of a plea deal and his agreement to drop his appeal of his previous conviction, Rezko pleaded guilty to wire fraud and was given a 7 1/2 year sentence to run concurrently with the 10 1/2-year sentence he is presently serving for his previous conviction.<ref name=uqovz />
===Release from federal prison===
In July 2015 Tony Rezko was released from federal prison to a halfway house in Chicago.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/7/71/752319/tony-rezko-released-halfway-house | work=Chicago Sun-Times | title=Onetime Obama donor Tony Rezko released to halfway house | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709063619/http://chicago.suntimes.com/news/7/71/752319/tony-rezko-released-halfway-house | archivedate=2015-07-09 | df= }}</ref>
==Ties to politicians==
===Ties to Rod Blagojevich=== Rezko's relationship with Illinois Governor [[Rod Blagojevich]] and his family were at the root of the federal corruption case which led to Rezko's conviction.<ref name=Fund-raising/> Rezko donated $117,652 to Blagojevich's campaigns,<ref name=salon/> and is credited by the prosecutor in his trial with having delivered [[Bundling (fundraising)|bundled]] contributions totalling almost $1.44 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/iln/hot/us_v_rezko_exhibits/2008_03_07/fob_chart_2.pdf |title=FOB Chart 2 |publisher=United States Department of Justice |date=2008-03-07 |accessdate=2008-05-10 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625021242/http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/iln/hot/us_v_rezko_exhibits/2008_03_07/fob_chart_2.pdf |archivedate=2008-06-25 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Since 1997, Blagojevich's wife, Patricia, has made at least $38,000 acting as Rezko's real-estate agent on several of his company's property acquisitions. When Blagojevich won the Illinois gubernatorial election in 2002, Rezko assisted Blagojevich in setting up the state's first Democratic administration in twenty years.<ref name=Fund-raising/> Rezko recommended many of his business associates and their relatives for positions within state government, three of whom were appointed to the state board that oversees hospital projects. the state's development board was run by another former Rezko business associate. Rezko and Republican fundraiser Stuart Levine were charged in a 24-count federal indictment for allegedly using Rezko's influence with public officials to demand millions of dollars in kickbacks from companies that wanted to do business with the state.<ref name=Fund-raising/><ref name=salon/> Levine pleaded guilty and served as the chief witness against Rezko at trial. Levine and several other witnesses implicated Blagojevich in the schemes.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-rezko-20mar20,0,1964917.story | title=Name on Levine's lips at trial: Blagojevich | work= Chicago Tribune | author=Coen, Jeff |author2=Secter, Bob | date=2008-03-20 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-rezko-02-both-may02,0,4933871.story | title= Ali Ata testifies he paid Rezko, donated to Blagojevich | work= Chicago Tribune | author=Secter, Bob |author2=Coen, Jeff |date=2008-05-01 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
The last indictment in [[Operation Board Games]] before Blagojevich himself was indicted was that of [[William F. Cellini]] who was indicted for conspiring with Rezko to [[Extortion|shake down]] Chicago-based Capri Capital to get a substantial contribution to Blagojevich in exchange for allowing Capri to manage $220 million in the Teachers Retirement System. After Thomas Rosenberg of Capri threatened to tell authorities, the plan was abandoned.<ref>[http://chicago.fbi.gov/dojpressrel/pressrel08/oct30_08a.pdf William F. Cellini, Sr., Indicted - fbi.gov - October 30, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320145638/http://chicago.fbi.gov/dojpressrel/pressrel08/oct30_08a.pdf |date=March 20, 2009 }}</ref> Capri has substantial investments in the [[Watergate complex]] and [[King Abdullah Economic City]].
===Ties to Barack Obama===
====History==== In 1990, after [[Barack Obama]] was elected president of the ''[[Harvard Law Review]]'', Rezmar Corp. offered him a job, which Obama turned down. Obama instead took a job with the firm of Davis, Miner, Barnhill & Galland,<ref>now Miner, Barnhill & Galland. {{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-obamalegal6apr06,0,26672.story |title=Obama's lawyer days: brief and not all civil rights |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Morain, Dan |date=2008-04-06 |accessdate=2008-05-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410052901/http://www.latimes.com/news/politics/la-na-obamalegal6apr06,0,26672.story |archivedate=2008-04-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> which primarily worked on civil rights cases. The firm also represented Rezmar and helped the company get more than $43 million in government funding. The firm's former senior partner, Allison S. Davis, later went into business with Rezko and, in 2003, was appointed to the Illinois State Board of Investment by Governor Blagojevich at Rezko's request.<ref name=Novak/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/644511,CST-NWS-davis11.article |title=How reform-minded City Hall critic became a cozy insider | work=Chicago Sun-Times | author=Novak, Tim | date=2007-11-11 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> On July 31, 1995, the first ever political contributions to Obama were $300 from a lawyer, a $5,000 loan from a car dealer, and $2,000 from two food companies owned by Rezko.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/353829,CST-NWS-rez23.article |title=Obama and his Rezko ties | work=Chicago Sun\Times | author=Novak, Tim | date=2007-04-23 | accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> Starting in 2003, Rezko was one of the people on Obama's U.S. Senate campaign finance committee, which raised more than $14 million.<ref name=Novak/> Rezko organized an early fundraiser for Obama that [[Chicago Tribune]] reporter David Mendell claims was instrumental in providing Obama with seed money for his U.S. Senate race.<ref name=chicagomag/> Obama in 2007-2008 identified over $250,000 in campaign contributions to various Obama campaigns as coming from Rezko or close associates, and said that he donated almost two-thirds of that amount to nonprofit groups.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/obama/844634,obamasun031508.article | title=Obama explains Rezko relationship to Sun-Times | work=Chicago Sun-Times | author=Chris Fusco |author2=David McKinney |author3=Tim Novak |author4=Abdon M. Pallasch | date=2008-03-16 | accessdate=2008-03-16}}</ref><ref name=NYT>{{cite news | author=Drew, Christopher |author2=McIntire, Mike | title=An Obama Patron and Friend Until an Indictment | work=The New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/14/us/politics/14rezko.html?pagewanted=1 | accessdate=2008-03-05 | date=2007-06-14}}</ref>
====Real estate dealings==== In 2005 Obama purchased a new home in the Kenwood District of Chicago for $1.65 million (which was $300,000 below the asking price but represented the highest offer on the property) on the same day that Rezko's wife, Rita Rezko, purchased the adjoining empty lot from the same sellers for the full asking price.<ref name="Land deal">{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/chi-0611010273nov01,0,1188525.story?page=1|title=Rezko owns vacant lot next to Obama's home|work=Chicago Tribune|author=Ray Gibson|author2=David Jackson |date=2006-11-01|accessdate=2008-03-04}}</ref> Obama acknowledged bringing his interest in the property to Rezko's attention,<ref>"Asked who approached her about the house, Schwan [the seller's broker] told Salon, 'I honestly don't remember. Tony Rezko lived across the street, so he'd been interested in the lot.'"{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2008/02/01/rezko/print.html|title=How close were Barack Obama and Tony Rezko?|publisher=Salon.com|author=McClelland, Edward|date=2008-02-01|accessdate=2008-05-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080418205340/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/2008/02/01/rezko/print.html|archivedate=2008-04-18|df=}}</ref> but denied any coordination of offers. According to Obama, while the properties had originally been a single property, the previous owners decided to sell the land as two separate lots, but made it a condition of the sales that they be closed on the same date. Obama also stated that the properties had been on the market for months, that his offer was the better of two bids, and that Ms. Rezko's bid was matched by another offer, also of $625,000, so that she could not have purchased the property for less.<ref name=mistake>{{cite news|author=McKinney, Dave|author2=Fusco, Chris |title=Obama on Rezko deal: It was a mistake|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=2006-11-05|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/124171,CST-NWS-obama05.article|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
After it had been reported in 2006 that Rezko was under federal investigation for influence-peddling, Obama purchased a 10-foot-wide strip of Ms. Rezko's property for $104,500, $60,000 above the assessed value.<ref name=Novak/><ref name="Land deal"/> According to ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' columnist, Mark Brown, "Rezko definitely did Obama a favor by selling him the 10-foot strip of land, making his own parcel less attractive for development."<ref>{{cite news|author=Brown, Mark|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/121104,CST-NWS-brown02.article|title=Obama's dealings with Rezko buy a parcel of questions|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=2006-11-02|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> Obama acknowledges that the exchange may have created the appearance of impropriety and stated "I consider this a mistake on my part and I regret it."<ref name=mistake/>
On December 28, 2006, Mrs. Rezko sold the property to a company owned by her husband's former business attorney. That sale of $575,000, combined with the earlier $104,500 sale to the Obamas, amounted to a [[net profit]] of $54,500 over her original purchase, less $14,000 for a fence along the property line and other expenses.<ref>The $54,500 figure is before any property tax and other expenses Ms. Rezko incurred during her ownership</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/politics/obama/chi-0702240237feb24,0,5895873.story|title=Rezko sells lot next to Obama|work=Chicago Tribune|author=Jackson, David|author2=Ray Gibson |date=2007-02-24|accessdate=2008-03-04}}</ref> In October 2007, the new owners put the still vacant land up for sale again, this time for $1.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/obama/595915,CST-NWS-obama10.article|title=Lot next to Obama can be yours for $1.5M|work=Chicago Sun-Times|author=Novak, Tim|date=2007-10-10|accessdate=2008-03-04}}</ref>
====Obama's letters==== In June 2007, the ''Sun-Times'' published a story about letters Obama had written in 1997 to city and state officials in support of a low-income senior citizen development project headed by Rezko and Davis. The project received more than $14 million in taxpayer funds, including $885,000 in development fees for Rezko and Davis. Of Obama's letters in support of the Cottage View Terrace apartments development, Obama spokesman Bill Burton said, "This wasn't done as a favor for anyone; it was done in the interests of the people in the community who have benefited from the project. I don't know that anyone specifically asked him to write this letter nine years ago. There was a consensus in the community about the positive impact the project would make and Obama supported it because it was going to help people in his district." Rezko's attorney responded that "Mr. Rezko never spoke with, nor sought a letter from, Senator Obama in connection with that project.<ref>{{cite news|author=Novak, Tim|title=Obama's letters for Rezko|work=Chicago Sun-Times|date=2007-06-13|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/politics/425305,CST-NWS-obama13.article|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
In the [[South Carolina Democratic Party]] presidential debate on January 21, 2008, Senator [[Hillary Clinton]] said that Obama had been associated with Rezko, whom she referred to as a [[slumlord|slum landlord]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Healy, Patrick|author2=Zeleny, Jeff |title=Obama and Clinton Tangle at Debate|work=The New York Times|date=2008-01-22|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/22/us/politics/22dems.html?em&ex=1201150800&en=6ae2b7e80f2fc272&ei=5087%0A|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' indicated that its own review showed Rezko played a deeper role in Obama's political and financial biography than Obama has acknowledged.<ref name=rezoba>{{cite news|author=Morain, Dan|author2=Hamburger, Tom |title=Obama dogged by ties to donor|work=Los Angeles Times|date=2008-01-23|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jan/23/nation/na-rezko23|accessdate=2011-10-10}}</ref> Within days of the debate, a photo of Rezko posing with [[Bill Clinton|Bill]] and [[Hillary Clinton]] surfaced. When asked about the photo, Hillary Clinton commented: "I probably have taken hundreds of thousands of pictures. I wouldn't know him if he walked in the door."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://youdecide08.foxnews.com/2008/01/25/photo-surfaces-showing-sen-clinton-posing-with-chicago-landlord-rezko|title=Photo Surfaces Showing Sen. Clinton Posing With Chicago Landlord Rezko|publisher=FOXNews|date=2008-01-25|accessdate=2008-05-10}}</ref>
===Ties to other politicians=== Rezko's first significant political act was hosting a fundraiser for [[Harold Washington]] during Washington's successful campaign to become Chicago's mayor.<ref name=salon/> He has since raised funds for many other politicians.<ref name=Sneed>{{cite news|author=Sneed, Michael|title=The Rezko scandal ...|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=2006-10-12|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/sneed/93087,CST-NWS-sneed12.article|accessdate=2008-03-05}}</ref> In addition to Blagojevich and Obama, prominent Democrats that Rezko or his company, Rezmar, have contributed money to, or fund-raised for, are Congressman [[Luis Gutierrez]], a friend for over two decades,<ref>{{cite news|first=Tim|last=Novak|title=Luis' deal with Rezko|date=2006-11-14|url=http://www.suntimes.com/news/metro/135305,CST-NWS-luis14.article|work =Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=2010-03-15}}</ref> Comptroller [[Daniel Hynes|Dan Hynes]], Attorney General [[Lisa Madigan]], Lieutenant Governor [[Pat Quinn (politician)|Pat Quinn]], former Chicago Mayors Daley and Washington, and former Cook County Board President [[John Stroger]].<ref name=Fund-raising/> Rezko has also raised money for Republicans, including former Illinois Governors [[Jim Edgar]] and [[George Ryan]].<ref name=chicagomag/> The late [[Rosemont, Illinois]], Mayor [[Donald Stephens]] and Rezko co-chaired a multimillion-dollar fund-raiser for President [[George W. Bush]] in 2003.<ref name=Novak2/><ref name=Sneed/>
Rezko headed the 2002 campaign finance committee for Stroger. Stroger appointed Rezko's wife, Rita, to the Cook County Employee Appeals Board, which hears cases brought by fired or disciplined workers. The part-time post pays $37,000 a year.<ref name=chicagomag/> A Rezko company had a contract to maintain pay telephones at the [[Cook County Jail]] under Stroger. The ''Chicago Sun-Times'' puts Rezko's contributions to Stroger at $148,300.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}

Eric Trump Wine Manufacturing LLC | homepage=http://www.trumpwinery.com | distribution= International | tasting= Open to the public }} '''Trump Winery''' (formerly '''Kluge Estate Winery and Vineyard''') is a Virginia [[winery]] situated on Trump Vineyard Estates in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. The vineyard was purchased by businessman (now [[U.S. President]]) [[Donald Trump]] in April 2011{{cite web|author=Annie Gowen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trump-buys-former-kluge-owned-winery/2011/04/07/AF8hn7wC_story.html |title=Trump buys former Kluge-owned winery |publisher=The Washington Post |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2012-06-19}} and was officially re-opened in October 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsplex.com/home/headlines/Trump_to_Debut_Albemarle_County_Winery_131055763.html |title=Trump Winery Opens in Albemarle County |publisher=Newsplex.com |date=2011-10-04 |accessdate=2012-06-19}} It is currently run by Trump's son [[Eric Trump|Eric]], under the name '''Eric Trump Wine Manufacturing LLC'''.{{cite web|last=Johnson |first=Richard |url=http://pagesix.com/2015/06/15/donald-trump-doesn't-own-trump-winery-his-son-does/ |title=Donald Trump doesn't own Trump Winery, his son does |publisher=Page Six |date=2015-06-15 |accessdate=2016-12-16}}{{cite web|author=Finance |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/meet-donald-trumps-five-children-2015-7 |title=Meet Donald Trump's five children |publisher=Business Insider |date= |accessdate=2016-12-16}} Trump Winery manufactures 36,000 cases of wine per year. Donald Trump has referred to it as "one of the largest wineries in the United States", although it actually ranks behind two other Virginia wineries that produce at least 60,000 cases of wine per year. http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/president-trump-owns-largest-winery-u-s-article-1.3414814 The current General Manager of the winery, Kerry Hannon Woolard, was a supporter of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]] and appeared as a guest speaker at the [[2016 Republican National Convention]] as well as other campaign events.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBHzK5wlhZI|title=FULL SPEECH: Kerry Woolard Trump Winery - Republican National Convention|first=|last=ABC15 Arizona|date=19 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 May 2017|via=YouTube}} ==Acquisition== Donald Trump purchased the vineyard out of foreclosure from three different banks, not from Patricia Kluge directly like some have suggested. Prior to being foreclosed, Patricia Kluge, former wife of American billionaire [[John Kluge]], did own the property. After her divorce in 1990, Kluge spent much of her remaining fortune over the following two decades, in 1999 establishing a winery{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/02/23/AR2011022302452.html|title=Va. winemaker's painstakingly built empire crumbled in months amid recession|first=Annie|last=Gowen|date=24 February 2011|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=washingtonpost.com}} and continuing to expand its production. She and her new husband also took out $65 million in loans to fund the expansion.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2011/03/10/patricia-kluge-lifestyle-billionaire-bankruptcy-estate.html|title=The Rise And Fall Of Patricia Kluge|last=Brennan|first=Morgan |publisher=Forbes|date=2011-03-10|access-date=2016-09-26}} In 2011 the couple defaulted on the loans.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2006943/Former-nude-model-richest-divorcee-history-declares-bankrupt.html|title=Where did all the money go? Former nude model who became 'richest divorcee in history' declares herself bankrupt|access-date=2016-09-26}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/01/business/patricia-kluge-loses-her-fortune-in-the-downturn.html|title=The Money Is Gone, but the Winery and a Woman’s Resolve Remain|author=|date=1 October 2011|website=The New York Times|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.c-ville.com/How_Patricia_Kluges_vineyard_reached_beyond_its_means/|title=How Patricia Kluge's vineyard reached beyond its means|author=|date=24 May 2011|website=C-VILLE Weekly|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web | url =http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/money-and-power/a871/patricia-kluge-interview/ | title =The Money Pit | last1 =DeSanctis | first1 =Marcia | author-link1 = | date =December 9, 2012 | website =TOWN&COUNTRY | publisher =Hearst Communications, Inc. | location = | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160313180307/http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/money-and-power/a871/patricia-kluge-interview/ | archive-date =2016-03-13 | dead-url =yes | access-date =August 17, 2017 | quote = She married one of the world's wealthiest men — and walked away with a record $100 million divorce settlement. How did she lose it all, and how does she plan to get it back? }} [[Bank of America]] acquired the mortgage on the mansion itself, but the surrounding property was still held in a Kluge family trust. Trump, a longstanding friend of Patricia Kluge, bought the {{convert|200|acres|km2|adj=off}} surrounding the property directly from the trust for $150,000. The bank later alleged that Trump subsequently arranged for "No Trespassing" signs to be placed around the property and to allow the lawns to become overgrown in order to ward off potential buyers and to give the appearance of Trump's exclusive access to the property, although the bank's property interest in the main house included right-of-way [[easement]]s. Trump then purchased the land from [[Bank of America]] for $3.6 million, a significant discount from the $16 million the bank had paid at the foreclosure auction to retain the property{{cite web|last=Frank |first=Robert |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304314404576413984028888352 |title=Donald Trump Picks Up Patricia Kluge's Virginia Assets|publisher=WSJ.com|date=2011-07-01 |accessdate=2012-06-19}} and to Kluge's original $100 million asking price the prior year.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/where-we-live/post/donald-trump-buys-kluge-estate-in-charlottesville/2012/09/26/bffa99de-0822-11e2-858a-5311df86ab04_blog.html|title=Donald Trump buys Kluge estate in Charlottesville|author=|date=|website=Washington Post|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/post/donald-trump-buys-patricia-kluges-mansion-for-bargain-price-of-65-million-now-owns-entire-estate/2012/09/26/87ffbde4-0826-11e2-a10c-fa5a255a9258_blog.html|title=Donald Trump buys Patricia Kluge's mansion for bargain price of $6.5 million; now owns entire estate|author=|date=|website=Washington Post|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trump-buys-former-kluge-owned-winery/2011/04/07/AF8hn7wC_story.html|title=Trump buys former Kluge-owned winery|first1=Annie|last1=Gowen|first2=Annie|last2=Gowen|date=7 April 2011|publisher=|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=washingtonpost.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.winesandvines.com/template.cfm?section=news&content=142158|title=Kluge Saga Continues in Virginia|author=|date=|website=winesandvines.com|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304314404576413984028888352|title=The Fall of the House of Kluge Leads to the Rise of the Yard of Trump|first=Robert|last=Frank|date=1 July 2011|publisher=WSJ.com|accessdate=17 August 2017|via=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2307081/Donald-Trumps-son-sued-Kluge-heir-purchase-Virginia-farm-winery-year.html|title=Donald Trump's son sued by Kluge heir over purchase over Virginia farm and winery last year|author=|date=|website=dailymail.co.uk|accessdate=17 August 2017}}{{cite web | url =https://www.washingtonian.com/2015/10/05/greatest-most-amazing-absolutely-huge-story-of-how-donald-trump-took-over-virginias-biggest-vineyard/ | title =The Greatest, Most Amazing, Absolutely HUGE Story of How Donald Trump Took Over Virginia's Biggest Vineyard | last1 =Kashino | first1 =Marisa M. | author-link1 = | date =2015-10-05 | website =Washingtonian | publisher =Washington Magazine, Inc. | location = | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20170817075714/https://www.washingtonian.com/2015/10/05/greatest-most-amazing-absolutely-huge-story-of-how-donald-trump-took-over-virginias-biggest-vineyard/ | archive-date =August 17, 2017 | dead-url =no | access-date =August 17, 2017 | quote = Trump knew this was his way in. In early 2011, he got the Kluge trust to sell him the yard for the bargain-basement price of $150,000. "That," says Eric, "is the art of the deal right there." }} In March 2016 Donald Trump stated publicly that he owned "the largest winery on the east coast,",{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/10/trump-wine-is-built-on-acres-of-lies.html|title=Trump Wine Is Built on Acres of Lies|last=Rothbaum|first=Noah|date=2016-03-10|website=The Daily Beast|publisher=The Daily Beast|access-date=2016-09-26}} although [[Politifact]] later determined this not to be true.{{cite news |last=Gorman |first=Sean |date=2016-03-21 |title=Donald Trump incorrectly says Virginia winery is the largest on East Coast |url=http://www.politifact.com/virginia/statements/2016/mar/21/donald-trump/donald-trump-says-virginia-winery-largest-east-coa/ |publisher=[[Politifact]] |access-date=2016-10-19}} Trump Winery makes 36,000 cases of wine per year compared to [[Williamsburg Winery]] and [[Chateau Morrisette Winery]], which produce at least 60,000 cases per year, according to The Virginia Wine Board. Trump Winery does have 227 acres of vineyard which makes it the largest vineyard in Virginia. ==Awards== Numerous gold medals at national and international [https://www.trumpwinery.com/winery/accolades/category/awards/ wine competitions] and best-in-class designations. 90 points from Wine Spectator for Blanc de Blanc, 91 points from James Suckling and Wine Enthusiast for Sparkling Reserve. In March 2013, ''[[Wine Enthusiast]]'' magazine gave the 2007 Trump SP Reserve a 91-point rating, which was at that time the highest rating for a still or sparkling Virginia wine.{{cite web|last=Berninger |first=Jack |url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/entertainment-life/columnists-blogs/jack-berninger/vines-and-wines-trump-winery-s-sp-reserve/article_4bc1f4b4-fa34-523a-a530-5c63817c15b2.html |title=Vines and Wines: Trump Winery's 2007 SP Reserve - TimesDispatch.com |publisher=Online.TimesDispatch.com |date=2013-03-24 |accessdate=2013-04-04}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.trumpwinery.com/}} {{Trump businesses}} {{coord|37.939100|-78.498677|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-VA|display=title}} [[Category:2011 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:Food and drink companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Wineries in Virginia]] [[Category:Business career of Donald Trump]] [[Category:Charlottesville, Virginia]]
